newsitem.title: UK: Russian journalists released in Chechnya, are well.
newsitem.headline: Russian journalists released in Chechnya, are well.

text.p: Four Russian journalists who were kidnapped and taken hostage in Chechnya over three months ago have been released, Russian news agencies reported early on Friday.
Interfax and Itar-Tass agencies, monitored by the British Broadcasting Corporation (BBC), said the freed journalists would return to Moscow shortly.
Itar-Tass quoted one of the four freed hostages, its correspondent Nikolay Zagnoyko, as saying by telephone that all four were "alive and well".
The other three journalists are from Radio Russia.
Interfax, quoting a source close to the leadership of the All-Russian Television and Radio Broadcasting Company, said no ransom had been paid to the kidnappers.
Itar-Tass reported that the four were expected to return to Moscow later on Friday.
Russian Mayak radio said the four were released at 5 a.m. (0100 gmt) on Friday.
It said they had been handed over to an official of the neighbouring republic of Dagestan and brought to the Dagestani capital, Makhachkala.
